1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• Rotashield(R), a tetravalent human-rhesus reassortant vaccine, was withdrawn from the market on October 14, 1999 because of a temporal association between the use of Rotashield(R) vaccine and the development of intussusception
  • Viral gastroenteritis due to Rotavirus; Prophylaxis: As of May 14, 2010, the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has recommended that clinicians resume use of the Rotarix(R) vaccine despite the presence of porcine circovirus type-1 DNA (PCV1) in the vaccine, as there is no evidence of a safety risk
  • Viral gastroenteritis due to Rotavirus; Prophylaxis: Rotarix(R), 1 mL ORALLY at 6 weeks of age, second dose after an interval of 4 weeks and prior to 24 weeks of age (manufacturer dosing) OR 2 dose series given at 2 and 4 months of age (guideline dosing)

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Rotashield(R), a tetravalent human-rhesus reassortant vaccine, was withdrawn from the market on October 14, 1999 because of a temporal association between the use of Rotashield(R) vaccine and the development of intussusception [1]
  • Viral gastroenteritis due to Rotavirus; Prophylaxis

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• severe allergic reaction (eg, anaphylaxis) after a previous dose or to a vaccine component (CDC); history of hypersensitivity to any component of the vaccine (manufacturer)
  • intussusception, history; fatal cases of intussusception have been reported
  • Severe Combined Immunodeficiency Disease (SCID), history
  • uncorrected congenital malformation of the gastrointestinal tract (eg, Meckel's diverticulum), history

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• acute illness with or without fever, moderate or severe; defer vaccination unless the benefit of protection outweighs the risk of an adverse reaction
  • bladder exstrophy
  • close contact to non-vaccinated individuals and/or individuals with immunodeficiencies; theoretical risk of transmission due to shedding of virus in stool
  • diarrhea or vomiting, acute; delay administration of vaccine
  • gastrointestinal disease, chronic
  • immunocompetence, altered, other than severe combined immunodeficiency disease (SCID)
  • latex sensitivity; tip cap and oral applicator contain dry natural latex rubber
  • spina bifida
  • report any adverse events to GlaxoSmithKline at 1-888-825-5249 or through the Vaccine Adverse Event Reporting System (VAERS) at 1-800-822-7967 or www.vaers.hhs.gov

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Gastrointestinal:Vomiting (8% to 13%)
  • Psychiatric:Irritability (11.4% to 52%)
  • Other:Patient shedding virus
Serious
  • Gastrointestinal:Diarrhea (3% to 4%), Intussusception of intestine
  • Respiratory:Pneumonia
  • Other:Death, Kawasaki disease

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: The rotavirus vaccine, live (Rotarix(R) is a live attenuated vaccine derived from the human 89-12 strain belonging to G1P[8] type, and contains at least 10(6) median Cell Culture Infective Dose of live, attenuated rotavirus. Although the exact mechanism of live rotavirus vaccine is unclear, it contains a live, attenuated human rotavirus that replicates in the small intestine and induces immunity against gastroenteritis.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Oral
  • for oral use only
  • reconstitute only with supplied diluent and administer within 24 hours of reconstitution
  • administer on inside of cheek while infant in reclining position
  • if infant regurgitates, spits out, or vomits during or after administration, it is not recommended to readminister the dose; remaining recommended doses should be given at the appropriate intervals
  • do mix with other solutions or vaccines

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Drug may cause fussiness/irritability, cough/runny nose, fever, loss of appetite, and vomiting.
  • Advise parent/caregiver to call healthcare professional if second dose is missed, as drug should be given on a fixed schedule.
